title: How to Dress Up a Salad with Edible Flowers

steps.headline: Know which to use.
steps.description:
Be aware that not all flowers are edible. If you have a particular one in mind, always research that specific type first to make sure it’s safe to eat. Otherwise, stick to popular favorites. Edible varieties that go particularly well with salads include:
Arugula
Chive
Hibiscus
Marigold. Pansies. Honeysuckle

steps.headline: Go organic.
steps.description: Keep in mind that, even if a specific flower is safe to eat in general, not all flowers are grown with consumption in mind. Avoid consuming any that have been treated with chemicals, like pesticides. Always use organic flowers, which are grown without any added chemicals.

steps.headline: Buy directly from source when possible.
steps.description:
If you have a farmer’s market nearby, purchase your flowers there. Inquire about growing methods with the sellers to ensure that they run an organic operation. If not, make sure you shop for flowers in your grocery store’s produce section, and not their florist section. If you’re still in doubt about whether they’re safe to eat, order online from companies that sell flowers specifically for cooking, like:
Gourmet Sweet Botanicals
Marx Foods
Melissa’s

steps.headline: Clean before use.
steps.description: Treat flowers just like any other produce. Always wash them before you start making any foods with them. Give them a shake to get rid of any dirt or insects. Place them in bowl of cold water and gently scrub them with your fingertips. Then place them on a paper towel so they can air-dry. If you don’t use them right way, dampen a fresh sheet of paper towel and use that to line an airtight container. Seal the flowers inside and refrigerate them. Use within a week of purchase.

steps.headline: Stir up your dressing.
steps.description: Pour the oil and vinegar into a small bowl. Add the salt and pepper. Mince your tarragon and add that as well. Use a whisk to mix them evenly.

steps.headline: Prep your veggies.
steps.description: First, wash your chervil, mache, and mesclun. Run them through a salad spinner to dry them off. Pick out the 30 fattest pea pods, split them open, and take out the peas. Rinse off your cucumber and slice it thinly. Then rinse off your radishes and slice them in half.

steps.headline: Toss your greens.
steps.description: Place your salad greens in a large mixing bowl. Drizzle three tablespoons of your dressing over them. Toss the greens to coat them evenly. Repeat as desired.

steps.headline: Plate your salad.
steps.description: Split the greens between your serving plates. Top each with cucumber, radishes, and split peas. Then add the remaining whole pea pods, or split those as well if you prefer.

steps.headline: Dress, decorate, and serve.
steps.description: Use a spoon to drizzle more dressing over your salads if desired, or keep it to the side so guests can do it themselves. Pick petals from your flowers and arrange them over each salad. Then top them with the remaining whole flowers and serve.

steps.headline: Make your dressing.
steps.description: First, chop your dill up into fine pieces. Add those to a small bowl or glass, along with the yogurt, horseradish sauce, and salt. Stir them until they’re evenly mixed. Add lemon juice to taste.

steps.headline: Combine your dry salad.
steps.description: Split your salad greens between serving plates. Top those with your tomatoes. Chop your smoked salmon up (or just rip it apart) into bite-size pieces and add those to the plate. Drop your olives over those.

steps.headline: Dress, decorate, and serve.
steps.description: Use a spoon to drizzle your dressing over the salads. Then arrange your flowers over them as you please. Serve them alongside crusty bread or rolls.

Using Flowers as Food Know which to use. Be aware that not all flowers are edible. If you have a particular one in mind, always research that specific type first to make sure it’s safe to eat. Otherwise, stick to popular favorites. Edible varieties that go particularly well with salads include:
Arugula
Chive
Hibiscus
Marigold. Pansies. Honeysuckle Go organic. Keep in mind that, even if a specific flower is safe to eat in general, not all flowers are grown with consumption in mind. Avoid consuming any that have been treated with chemicals, like pesticides. Always use organic flowers, which are grown without any added chemicals. Buy directly from source when possible. If you have a farmer’s market nearby, purchase your flowers there. Inquire about growing methods with the sellers to ensure that they run an organic operation. If not, make sure you shop for flowers in your grocery store’s produce section, and not their florist section. If you’re still in doubt about whether they’re safe to eat, order online from companies that sell flowers specifically for cooking, like:
Gourmet Sweet Botanicals
Marx Foods
Melissa’s Clean before use. Treat flowers just like any other produce. Always wash them before you start making any foods with them. Give them a shake to get rid of any dirt or insects. Place them in bowl of cold water and gently scrub them with your fingertips. Then place them on a paper towel so they can air-dry. If you don’t use them right way, dampen a fresh sheet of paper towel and use that to line an airtight container. Seal the flowers inside and refrigerate them. Use within a week of purchase. Decorating a Garden Salad Stir up your dressing. Pour the oil and vinegar into a small bowl. Add the salt and pepper. Mince your tarragon and add that as well. Use a whisk to mix them evenly. Prep your veggies. First, wash your chervil, mache, and mesclun. Run them through a salad spinner to dry them off. Pick out the 30 fattest pea pods, split them open, and take out the peas. Rinse off your cucumber and slice it thinly. Then rinse off your radishes and slice them in half. Toss your greens. Place your salad greens in a large mixing bowl. Drizzle three tablespoons of your dressing over them. Toss the greens to coat them evenly. Repeat as desired. Plate your salad. Split the greens between your serving plates. Top each with cucumber, radishes, and split peas. Then add the remaining whole pea pods, or split those as well if you prefer. Dress, decorate, and serve. Use a spoon to drizzle more dressing over your salads if desired, or keep it to the side so guests can do it themselves. Pick petals from your flowers and arrange them over each salad. Then top them with the remaining whole flowers and serve. Topping a Smoked Salmon Salad Make your dressing. First, chop your dill up into fine pieces. Add those to a small bowl or glass, along with the yogurt, horseradish sauce, and salt. Stir them until they’re evenly mixed. Add lemon juice to taste. Combine your dry salad. Split your salad greens between serving plates. Top those with your tomatoes. Chop your smoked salmon up (or just rip it apart) into bite-size pieces and add those to the plate. Drop your olives over those. Dress, decorate, and serve. Use a spoon to drizzle your dressing over the salads. Then arrange your flowers over them as you please. Serve them alongside crusty bread or rolls. Finished.
